author: sky.cactus
content:
What ultimately convinced me to support the ice age was two things:
1. Ethereum needs to constantly be adapting.  The world is changing too fast for pretty much any tech to be able to ride a high for long without adaptation.
2. In the case of a contentious change, both sides of a fork *need* to have at least one developer willing and able to regularly apply client updates and a system in place for vetting and distributing an updated client.

author: jgm
content:
Not convinced about 1, at least when you have hard forks like Muir Glacier that do nothing other than push out the ice age.  It's just a spinning plate you have to touch now and again, but has no immediate value outside of that.

2, perhaps but you're talking cloning a repository, making a one-line patch and running `make all` (in the case of geth, at least).  I think that's a pretty minimal barrier.

I think a project should be adapted because there is a benefit to doing so, not because there is some forcing function requiring it.  I hope that there is no attempt to implement similar inside Eth2.

author: sky.cactus
content: Re (2) a one line patch, plus build and deployment, plus distribution and awareness, plus fork timing coordination, plus supporting multiple clients is all a pretty high barrier to entry pragmatically.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!187490121698770945> could give you a better idea of how much effort it takes to get something as simple as Muir Glacier out.

author: chikka651
content: whats pragmatical here

author: sky.cactus
content: And in fact, that high barrier is why (1) is relevant.  Even if there are useful things that need to go out, coordinating core devs to *actually* push a release out is hard.  Ensuring that the uncomfortable process must be exercised regularly ensures that we have a smooth process for it.

author: sky.cactus
content:
In fact, I would weakly argue that we should have quarterly ice ages or something to ensure that the core devs have a smoothly running deployment process (including all of the "other stuff like coordination").
> If it hurts, do it more often.  -- https://sharpend.io/if-it-hurts-do-it-more-often

author: jgm
content:
Not convinced that having a smooth process for a release (pushing back an ice age) translates to having a smooth process for all releases.  Developers tend to automate the boring bits, so if it is frequent there will be some sort of "create new release with pushed back ice age" button to build and package the last major release + a new ice age block height, and it will become an administrative issue rather than one requiring any real thought.

SSL certificates are a good example of this.  You end up building scripts to periodically update them, but when it comes to doing something meaningful like adding a new domain to the certificate it doesn't give you any benefit over not having scripts to periodically update them.

author: jgm
content: (On a separate technical note, not sure how some sort of ice age would be implemented in Ethereum 2.  The underlying unit of block production is a slot, which is hard-coded to 12 seconds.  Changing that to a variable would make a pretty big mess of things, so it would more likely be something like extending the range of block proposers beyond the active set by a time-based amount, causing an increasing % of blocks to not have any real proposer, but that would be quite lumpy on the micro level.)

author: sky.cactus
content: The piece that is very hard to automate, but would be great if it could be, is the human coordination aspects.  We have not historically automated these yet they are massive pain points.

author: sky.cactus
content: What are the HF block numbers for all the testnets, what are the HF block numbers for mainnet, announcements to all of the appropriate stakeholders of a pending HF, etc.

author: jgm
content:
True, but isn't there already co-ordination going on for functional upgrades?  And if not, probably for a good reason (deciding on what to put in, building interfaces, whatever)?

I do hear you, it just feels a bit like additional busy work in a world where everyone is already running at 100%.  Guess we'll see as we get closer to July as to if we end up with another ice age hard fork on the tail of an actual upgrade.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is, but it hurts (so we should do more of it).

author: sky.cactus
content: It is *very* easy to get lulled into a "there is no rush, we can just keep poking".  If we had a hard fork every 3 months though, then we can change the pattern to "if it is ready for this hard fork, then it goes into this hard fork" instead of a pattern of "build a bunch of stuff until it is all done so we only have to do one hard fork".

author: sky.cactus
content: I think most core developers agree that it would be *better* to do more frequent smaller HFs (at least that is the sentiment I got when this was discussed a while back), but without a forcing function it just doesn't happen because it is painful.

author: jgm
content:
Smaller functional hard forks with a higher frequency I agree with, surely that would be easier to create with some sort of "no more than _x_ EIPs per hard fork" rule, so the desired EIPs stack up to a set limit when the co-ordination process starts.

Anyway, it is what it is and I'm not bothered enough to suggest changing it, just don't want it turning up in Ethereum 2 (although I recognize that's kind-of changing it)

author: sky.cactus
content: Rules that can be bent or ignored likely will be.  Rules that cannot be ignored likely won't be.  The idea is to set yourself up so you *cannot* bend/break the rules you set for yourself in the past.

author: sky.cactus
content: FWIW, when I proposed removing the ice age for Ethereum a while back it encountered a lot of resistance from the core devs.  I suspect that at the moment the ETH1 core devs aren't aware that you all removed that mechanic, and once they are made aware they'll request it be added.  If you strongly believe that it **should** be removed (whether that is now or at PoS), then my recommendation is to start prepping your argumentation material.  ðŸ˜„
